message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The T cells in the cortex of the thymus are still in the process of differentiation and are not yet fully differentiated into Th1 or Th2 cells, so option (B) and (C) can be ruled out. The fact that they are undergoing positive and negative selection based on their ability to bind cortical epithelial cells expressing MHC molecules suggests that they are CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, as both types of T cells undergo this process in the thymus. Option (D) is incorrect because it suggests that the T cells are only CD4+ and not CD8+.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T cells during this phase of differentiation are referred to as double positive cells, meaning they express both CD4 and CD8 surface markers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD4+ and CD8+ are both markers of mature T cells and are expressed during the differentiation phase in the thymus. Th2 cells are a specific subset of mature T cells, and T cell precursors are in an earlier stage of differentiation. Therefore, option A is the best choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. During the early phases of thymic T cell differentiation, T cells express both CD4 and CD8 molecules, and are known as double-positive (DP) thymocytes. As they undergo positive and negative selection, some T cells will become single-positive CD4+ or CD8+ cells, whereas others will undergo apoptosis if they fail to interact with MHC molecules on cortical epithelial cells. Therefore, the T cells in this phase of differentiation would be CD4+ and CD8+.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD4+ and CD8+ are co-receptors found on the surface of T cells and are involved in their activation. The fact that the T cells undergo apoptosis when they do not bind to cortical epithelial cells expressing MHC molecules suggests that they have successfully undergone positive selection, which results in the development of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. Th2 cells are a subset of CD4+ T cells that are involved in the humoral immune response. T cell precursors are immature cells that have not yet undergone differentiation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The T cells isolated from the cortex of the thymus are in the process of positive selection, during which T cells that do not bind cortical epithelial cells expressing MHC molecules die by apoptosis. This process will result in the selection of T cells that are capable of recognizing MHC molecules, leading to CD4+ and CD8+ T cell lineages. Therefore, the correct answer is (A). Th2 is a subset of T helper cells that produce cytokines to help in the defense against extracellular parasites. T cell precursor refers to immature T cells that have not undergone the process of positive and negative selection in the thymus. CD4+ refers to T helper cells that recognize MHC class II molecules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD4+ and CD8+ are markers expressed by different T cell subsets, and both markers are present during early T cell differentiation in the thymus. The T cells that do not bind to cortical epithelial cells undergo apoptosis, indicating a process of negative selection in T cell development. Th2 cells are a subset of CD4+ T cells that produce cytokines to promote humoral immune responses. T cell precursors are undifferentiated cells that have not yet committed to becoming T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. T cells in the cortex of the thymus go through positive selection, during which they must bind cortical epithelial cells expressing MHC molecules to survive. Only T cells that are able to bind both MHC class I and class II will mature and become CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. Thus, option (A) is the correct answer. The other options are not relevant to this stage of T cell differentiation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. During positive selection, T cells that interact too weakly or too strongly with self MHC molecules undergo apoptosis. The surviving T cells will express both CD4 and CD8 coreceptors, making them CD4+ and CD8+. Option (B) Th2 refers to a subset of helper T cells, option (C) T cell precursor is a general term for immature T cells, and option (D) only refers to T cells expressing CD4 coreceptors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD4+ and CD8+ are T cell receptor co-receptors that are expressed on T cells during the positive selection process that occurs in the thymus cortex. During this process, T cells that are able to recognize self-MHC molecules are positively selected and those that cannot undergo apoptosis. Therefore, the T cells at this phase of differentiation would be CD4+ and CD8+. Th2 cells are a subset of T helper cells, and T cell precursors are immature T cells that have not yet undergone selection in the thymus.
